collection_comments: estimated from map; Absheron Peninsula, village of Dzhangi\r\n\r\nAzerbaijan, ‚Äúright bank of Sumgait River (Dzhengichai) three km northeast of Dzhengi guest house‚Äù (Mchedlidze, 1964 [1988:77], from Weber, 1928). Riabinin (1938:1 [Russian text], 173 [English summary]) stated that the remains of this animal were found ‚Äúat the foot of an elevation located north of Sumgait River (Djenghi-Chai) at a distance of 3 km from the Djenghi Inn,‚Äù but Riabinin did not give his source for that information, which is somewhat different from that of Weber (1928). Mchedlidze (1976 [1984:1]) gave the locality as the ‚Äúwestern part of Apsheronsk Peninsula, Dzhangi village.‚Äù We have not been able to determine the exact location of the Dzhengi guest house/inn; thus, the exact type locality remains uncertain. The most likely possibilities include outcrops in thePerekishkyul area, which have yielded many fossil whales (Mchedlidze, 1964), or outcrops along the Sumgait River just northeast of the town of Jangi, whose coordinates are 40 300 1000 W, 49 150 5100 E. When we initially looked into this ques- tion, we were confused by the reference to ‚ÄòSumgait River (Dzhengichai)‚Äô until we learned that the two names ‚ÄòSumgait‚Äô "and ‚ÄòDzhengichai‚Äô (also anglicized as ‚ÄòJangichai‚Äô from Azerbai- jani) both apply to the same river; ‚ÄòDzhengichai‚Äô being its name in the mountainous region west of the Apsheronsk Peninsula and ‚ÄòSumgait‚Äô after it enters the plain at the western margin of the Peninsula and flows northeastward to the coastal town of Sumgait (personal communication, Akif Alizadeh to A.E.S., 2 May 2012). Thus, the name ‚ÄòSumgait River (Dzhengichai)‚Äô means the Dzhengi portion of the river. We have also learned that Weber collected the remains of Mirocetus 15‚Äì20 km south-west of the city of Sumgait (pers. comm., A. Alizadeh to A.E.S., 2 May 2012) and, according to Weber (1928), on the right bank of the Dzhengi ( D Jangichai) River, and not on the Sumgait portion of the river as reported by Riabinin (Sanders & Geisler, 2015).
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Maikop Group, most likely Lower Mai- kop beds, which are uppermost Rupelian or lowermost Chattian in age. Riabinin (1938) reported the holotype of Mirocetus as having come from the upper Maikop beds; however, Mchedlidze (1964) attributes this to two errors by Riabinin (1938): (1) he did not recognize that cetaceans are derived from multiple levels in the Maikop Group and (2) he assumed that the holotype of Mir- ocetus came from the most productive horizon, which is either latest Oligocene or earliest Miocene in age.\r\n(Sanders & Geisler, 2015).

comments_evaluation: 41.3 changed to 41.2 based on ICS 2022; From PBDB: Lower Dammam, Midra Shales n. 10. Subsequently, the Rus and Dammam formations were assigned to the Middle Eocene Lutetian stage based on the pervence of latest Paleocene/Early Eocene planktonic foraminifera in the underlying Umm Er Radhuma Formation (Hasson, 1985; El-Nakhal, 1988). On the basis of the recorded fauna, the age of the Dammam Formation in Qatar was revised to Middle/Late Lutetian age. Hewaidy and Al Saad (1993) assigned the Midra and Dukhan members a Middle Lutetian age and Umm Bab and Abaruq members a Late Lutetian age.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; clay pit situated about 1.5 km N of Gram in Southern Jutland
comments_evaluation:
From PBDB: Tortonian-basal Pliocene, from the middle part of the typical Gram clay (20 m in the type locality section where it was divided into five faunal assemblage zones by Rasmussen (1966))
conformably overlies the Hodde Fm (Serravallian) and is unconformably overlain by Quaternary deposits (AH, based on Roth and Hoedemakers 2005)

The uppermost portion of the Gram Formation correlates with foraminiferal zone N17 (8.6‚Äì5.7 Ma [20, 54]) [208] and ‚Äì within the clay pit ‚ÄìNorth Sea foraminiferal zone NSB 13b [209] and dinoflagellate zone D19b (8.7‚Äì7.5 Ma [54]), as judged from the last appearance of Spiniferites pseudofurcatus [208, 210]. Together, these dates imply a late Tortonian age (8.6‚Äì7.5 Ma). (Marx & Fordyce, 2015)

Gram Formation, Late Miocene [15]: based on the composition of associated mollusc fauna, the specimen can be accurately identified as belonging to layer 3 or 4 of the Gram Clay Formation [15,16] which are dated to mid-Torto- nian, ca. 9.9‚Äì8 mya according to a combined study of geomagnetic variation, dinoflagellates and malacofauna [16‚Äì18]. (Gol'din & Steeman, 2015).

comments_evaluation:
From PBDB: base of this formation (original name translates as "Artoles Marls and Limestones")

Villanueva-Amadoz et al. 2015: The presence of cf. Arecipites microfoveolatus Ibrahim, Afropollis sp. and Stellatopollis barghoornii Doyle from the basal levels of Artoles Formation suggests a late Barremian age (Pons et al. 2013). The schizacean fern spore content supports a Barremian age.

Bover-Arnal et al. 2016: Sr values from samples suggest a middle/late Early Barremian age for the lower-middle part of the Artoles Formation, and a Late Barremian age for the upper part. Previously the Barremian‚ÄìAptian boundary has been placed within the Artoles Formation, but late Barremian ammonites have been found in the overlying Morella Formation, ruling out an early Aptian age for the Artoles Formation.

collection_comments: stated in text; Cerro La Cruz, southern flank of the Serrania La Baragua, NW ate of Lara State, approximately 4 km NW from Caserio La Mesa. It can be reached by the road between La Mesa and San Jacinto.
comments_evaluation: Early Miocene stated in the text; From PBDB: The Castillo Formation has formely been regarded as late Oligocene in age (Wheeler, 1960), but more recent workers, including this reference regard it to be early Miocene. The Castillo Formation unconformably overlies Eocene rocks of the Misoa Formation, although neither upper or lower contacts can be viewed at the collection's section. The section comprises 87 m of clayey marls interbedded with numerous thin (<1 m) hardground units. The strata are underlain and overlain by sandstones, and the upper 15 m are gypsiferous. Most fossils were collected near the base of the exposures. The turtle skull was collected from the top, however.

collection_name: Cerro La Cruz, Castillo Formation, Unit C
collection_comments: stated in text; Cerro La Cruz, southern flank of the Serrania La Baragua, in the north-west of Lara State.
comments_evaluation: Age based on Rincon et al., 2014; From PBDB: Unit C (Rincon et al. 2014)\r\n\r\nRincon et al., 2014: Four isotopic dates using Strontium (87 Sr/86 Sr), from the Cerro La Cruz locality were obtained, which bracket of the sediments to between 17.21 to 19.27 Ma, confirming an Early Miocene age for this locality.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; Murray River near Wellington, south-east of Adelaide. Likely from Tailem Bend, 14 km upstream from Wellington, where the Ettrick Formation crops out (Pledge & Rothausen, 1977). "It is in this same area, just south of Tailem Bend, that the Ettrick Formation makes one of its few surface appearances, as a hard, pale greenish - grey, finely glauconitic marl (Ludbrook 1961 p, 38), occurring as a bench at present pool level of the river. This pool level is largely artificial, following the installation of barrages at the mouth of the river, in the 1930's, to control depth and salinity. It is therefore probable that the extent of outcrop of the Ettrick Formation was far greater circa 1880. Being glauconitic, and therefore of a somewhat reducing origin, the Ettrick Formation would yield teeth of a decidedly dark grey-black, colouration.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: "Interestingly, a tooth of the Oligocene shark Carcharodon angustidens. collected at Tailem Bend in 1936, has the same dark preservation as the Metasqualodon and Hexanchus teeth, and other shark teeth from reducing sediments, and adds support for the provenance of Metasqualodon being the Ettrick Formation." (Pledge & Rothausen, 1977). Associated plankton include Turborotalia euapertura, Guembelitria triseriata and Chiloguembelina cubensis, suggesting a Late Oligocene (P21 Zone) age (Gallagher & Gourley, 2007). Metasqualodon teeth likely came from the upper part of the unit (Pledge & Rothausen, 1977).

based on political unit; Although the matrix containing the specimen described here (‚Äúcf. Pseudocorax sp.‚Äù of Shimada, 1997) is undoubtedly from the Smoky Hill Chalk of western Kansas and was likely collected by the Sternberg family in the early 1900s, the material lacks specific specimen information that would conclusively tie it with an existing KUVP number. Intriguingly, in 1911, Charles H. Sternberg (1911:72) noted: ‚ÄúFurther, I have in my laboratory to-day a new species of shark, found this season on Hackberry creek whose vertebrae are half as large as the Lamna we secured. The teeth are so small that some of them can only be seen with a magnifying glass‚Äù. The description of the teeth appears to be consistent with that can be observed in KUVP 141876 (and the ‚ÄúLamna‚Äù in Sternberg‚Äôs writing may refer to Cretoxyrhina). However, because KUVP 141876 as preserved does not contain any vertebrae, whether or not the shark specimen described by Sternberg (1911) and KUVP 141876 are the same specimen cannot be ascertained. It should be noted that ‚ÄòHackberry Creek‚Äô in this context implies southwestern Trego County, Kansas (Sternberg, 1911:71).

comments_evaluation: From PBDB: The vertebrate-rich calcarenite unit discussed in this paper is located approximately 2.5 m above the contact between the noncalcareous Graneros Shale and calcareous Greenhorn Limestone. Ostrea beloiti and I. cf. I. rutherfordi range from the Middle Cenomanian (96 Ma) to the early Late Cenomanian (ca. 94.6 Ma), and from middle Middle Cenomanian (ca. 95 Ma) to possibly as late as early Late Cenomanian (ca. 94.55 Ma), respectively (Kauffman et al., 1993, fig. 7). Thus, the concurrent age of occurrence for these two bivalve taxa is 95‚Äì94.5 Ma, which dictates that the vertebrate-rich horizon is no older than the middle Middle Cenomanian (ca. 95 Ma). Based upon the similarity of our data with those presented by Kauffman et al. (1993, fig. 7), and considering the close proximity of the calcarenite layers to the X-bentonite, we think that the age of the vertebrate-rich horizon is somewhere between middle Middle Cenomanian (ca. 95 Ma) and late Middle Cenomanian (ca. 94.7 Ma).

Santana Formation suggested to be early Albian in age by Heimhofer & Hochuli (2010) on the basis of palynomorphs
Cerqueira et al. 2021:The Romualdo Formation was recently considered as Aptian in age, based on palynomorph, foraminifera and ostracod data (Arai and Assine 2020; Melo et al. 2020). 
From Melo et al. 2020: In summary, this integrated study of foraminifera, ostracodes and other microfossil data from the Romualdo Formation indicates that the local Alagoas Stage (Ostracoda Zone RT-011) can now be constrained to the Aptian. Arai and Assine 2020 also support that the Romualdo Formation and Santana Group is entirely Aptian in age.

collection_comments: stated in text; Map sheet: Bubbarp 3D 7f, Ed. 1-Nov. 1975 (economical map, 1:10,000); coordinates 623722 137729. The western section (2 m east of the western limit of the quarry) exposed, from the bottom to the top, 1.15 m fine-grained calcarenite, 0.05 m cross-bedded sand, 0.65 m sandy calcisiltite with a basal conglomerate containing fist-sized phosphatized angular limestone fragments. The base of the conglomerate is used as reference level. On top of the Cretaceous is a 1.0-m-thick cover of Quaternary strata. The top of the Cretaceous part of the western section is situated 0.8 m below the corresponding level of the eastern section.

collection_comments: stated in text; Map sheet Bara 2C:26, Ed. 1987 (economic map "Gula Kartan" in Swedish, 1:20,000), coordinates 6165 1330. East of the village of Kvarnby, glacial rafts (Schollen) of a very pure white chalk are quarried by the Malm√∂krita AB company. The tilted Schollen are several hundred meters long and up to 30 m thick and are interbedded in a till. The rejected > 200 micron fraction is dumped into two abandoned quarries situated just west of Angdala Farm. Collected from the northwestern corner of the southern quarry, located immediately south of the sieving station.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Probably mid-Maastrichtian. Brood (1972) suggested a late Early Maastrichtian age for the Kvarnby chalk. Based on foraminifera, Holland (in Ringberg et al. (1984) referred the strata to the Late, but not latest, Maastrichtian.

(2007). It may no longer be accessible for collecting as an apartment complex and well pad site occupy much of the previous collecting ground.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: In this area, the Pawpaw Shale is of Mortoniceras (Subschloenbachia) rostratum Zone age (late Albian) as this ammonite index taxon occurs in the basal part of the overlying Mainstreet Limestone and in the underlying Weno Limestone.

collection_comments: estimated from map; A series of temporary trenches excavated in 2012‚Äì2015 near the old sandstone quarry south of Kopiec.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 105.3 and 99.6 to 113 and 100.5 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: Theoretically, the shark tooth collection obtained by screen washing at Kopiec could have originated from the whole sampled interval, which embraces the upper part of unit 2 and the whole unit 3 (see above). However, practically no vertebrate material has been observed during the present project in sands or weakly phosphatized sandstone nodules situated below the top of unit 2 (there is, however, a single pliosaur vertebral centrum preserved in one such nodule in an old collection, reported by Bardet et al. 2016). In contrast, the interval spanning the top of unit 2 (layer of well-lithified sandy phosphatic nodules and clasts) to the top of unit 3 contains abundant vertebrate fossils and constitutes the most fossiliferous part of the Annopol succession. All shark material collected is assumed to have originated from this interval. In view of the ranges of ammonites present in this interval, the biostratigraphic dating of the shark material is between the middle Albian Hoplites dentatus Zone to the upper upper Albian Mortoniceras perinflatum Zone. Ammonites in unit 3, mainly preserved as attachment scars on oyster shells, are mid-'Vraconnian' (late late Albian) forms typical of the Mortoniceras rostratum Zone or, more probably, the Mortoniceras perinflatum Zone. There is a hiatus on top of unit 3, embracing the Praeschloenbachia briacensis Zone, which spans the Albian‚ÄíCenomanian boundary. The concretionary aggregates near the top of unit 3 comprise up to three generations of phosphatic clasts, testifying to a multiphase origin and reworking of the phosphate material.

collection_comments: stated in text; 440 kg sample, Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36'01.2", E114¬∞14'00.9"
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Bed 1, 'upper' Gearle Siltstone, uppermost upper Albian (CC9b). The presence of Eiffellithus casulus, Eiffellithus turrisseifellii and Watznaueria britannica without Hayesites albiensis and Corollithion kennedyi places this assemblage in uppermost Albian calcareous nannofossil Subzone CC9b of Perch-Nielsen (1985).

collection_comments: stated in text; 18.2 kg sample, Thirindine Point west, S27¬∞36 π02.6 ∫, E114¬∞13 π43.2 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Bed 2, 'upper' Gearle Siltstone, uppermost upper Albian (CC9b). The presence of Helenea chiastia, Eiffellithus turriseiffelii, Gartnerago praeobliqum and Lordia xenotus without Hayesites albiensis and Corollithion kennedyi indicates the uppermost upper Albian part of Zone CC9b.

collection_comments: stated in text; 27.4 kg sample, Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36 π02.6 ∫, E114¬∞14 π01.4 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Bed 3, 'upper' Gearle Siltstone, lowermost Cenomanian (CC9c). The sample from Bed 3 contains similar species to those of Bed 2, with the addition of Corollithion kennedyi, Gartnerago nanum and early forms of Lithraphidites eccentricus. These taxa, with the presence of Lordia xenotus and Watznaueria britannica, indicate the lowest Cenomanian Subzone CC9c.

collection_comments: stated in text; 67.9 kg sample, Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞35 π47.0 ∫, E114¬∞13 π59.8 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Bed 4, uppermost 'upper' Gearle Siltstone, middle/late Cenomanian. Two samples from Bed 4 (NL 2 and 5), the highest stratigraphic unit of the 'upper' Gearle in the Thirindine Point area, are barren of calcareous nannofossils.

collection_comments: stated in text; Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36 π1.2 ∫, E114¬∞14 π00.9 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Densely laminated part of the Haycock Marl, above the basal 2-3 cm of greensand but below the blotchy interval located about 0.15-0.25 m above the base of the unit. Uppermost upper Cenomanian part of calcareous nannofossil Subzone CC10b. The sample from the basal, densely laminated part of Haycock Marl at NL 1 contains E. turriseiffellii but lacks Helenea chiastia, Axopodorhabdus biramiculatus, Lithraphidites eccentricus, C. kennedyi and Gartnerago nanum. In addition, no specimens of Quadrum gartnerii, Eprolithus octopetalus or Eprolithus moratus were observed. This association of taxa indicates Subzone CC10b of latest late Cenomanian age.

collection_comments: stated in text; Thirindine Point east, no GPS coordinates. Collected at several closely spaced locations in the same area over several fieldtrips in 1994-1995 and providing the elasmobranch material from the basal Haycock Marl described by Siverson 1996.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Densely laminated part of the Haycock Marl, above the basal 2-3 cm of greensand but below the blotchy interval located about 0.15-0.25 m above the base of the unit. Uppermost upper Cenomanian part of calcareous nannofossil Subzone CC10b. The sample from the basal, densely laminated part of Haycock Marl at NL 1 contains E. turriseiffellii but lacks Helenea chiastia, Axopodorhabdus biramiculatus, Lithraphidites eccentricus, C. kennedyi and Gartnerago nanum. In addition, no specimens of Quadrum gartnerii, Eprolithus octopetalus or Eprolithus moratus were observed. This association of taxa indicates Subzone CC10b of latest late Cenomanian age. Note that the unit is referred to as the 'Beedagong Claystone' in Siverson (1996).

collection_comments: stated in text; Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36 π1.2 ∫, E114¬∞14 π00.9 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Basal 2-3 cm of of the Haycock Marl. We therefore cautiously refer the basal glauconite layer to the uppermost upper Cenomanian part of CC10b. The overlying densely laminated part of Haycock Marl at NL 1 contains E. turriseiffellii but lacks Helenea chiastia, Axopodorhabdus biramiculatus, Lithraphidites eccentricus, C. kennedyi and Gartnerago nanum. In addition, no specimens of Quadrum gartnerii, Eprolithus octopetalus or Eprolithus moratus were observed. This association of taxa indicates Subzone CC10b of latest late Cenomanian age.

collection_comments: stated in text; Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36 π1.2 ∫, E114¬∞14 π00.9 ∫
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Calcareous nannofossil Subzone CC10b, most likely lowermost lower Turonian part. The lens is located in the lowermost quarter of the Haycock Marl but above the densely laminated, basal part. A sample from an isolated, phosphatic lens contains very poorly preserved and sparse (<1 specimen per 2 FOV) calcareous nannofossil assemblage. The lens's stratigraphic position, just above the densely laminated basal part of the Haycock Marl, and nannofossil content (e.g., E. octopetalus) indicate an age comparable with that of Unit A at NL 4. The lower four of these samples, all in Bed A, have assemblages that include Eprolithus octopetalus and Ahmuellerella octoradiata. Both of these species have first appearance datums (FAD) just below the Cenomanian‚ÄìTuronian boundary (Corbett et al. 2014). The lack of Quadrum gartnerii or other Turonian species prohibits definitive placement of these samples in the lowermost Turonian; however, the FAD of Q. gartnerii is often difficult to observe because of the extreme rarity of this species near the base of its range. These samples are assigned to the upper part of CC10b.

collection_comments: stated in text; Thirindine Point east, S27¬∞36 π1.2 ∫, E114¬∞14 π00.9 ∫

collection_comments: stated in text; Pekarskyi (coordinates: 49¬∞ 42.568'N, 31¬∞ 32.558'E), Kaniv Natural Reserve
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Cretaceous sections cropping out in the study area are part of Kaniv dislocations, which refer to the effects of tectonics (glaciogenic dislocation) over the Mesozoic successions (Krochak et al., 2016). The Kaniv dislocations belong to the Burim formation and are commonly exposed in many ravines on the territory of Kaniv Natural Reserve lying on top of the Callovian clays (Krochak et al., 2016). The Burim formation was previously considered Albian in age (Krochak et al., 2016), but more recent macrofaunal, foraminiferal and palynological studies suggested a late Albiane-early Cenomanian age (Ivannik et al., 2014). The lower part of the formation (approximately 20 m) is considered late Albian in age and is characterized by the presence of the ammonite species Mortoniceras inflatum, which indicates an ammonite zone right before the 'Vraconian' according to the stratigraphical data from Central European Basin. Top 40-60 m yielded fossil remains of various foraminifera (e.g., Lingulogavelinella praeformosa, Thalmanninella appenninica) that suggest a latest Albian to early Cenomanian age, including the 'Vraconian' stage (Krochak et al., 2016). Popova et al. (2015) also considered the possibility of the upper layers being Early Cenomanian in age. However, this hypothesis was based on incorrect identifications of several elasmobranch taxa. Paraisurus macrorhizus and Cretoxyrhina vraconensis findings indicate a late Albian age for the sampled deposits.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; At 4760 Murphy Canyon Road, at elevation of 104 m (340 ft.) on W side of Murphy Canyon, 5746 m (18,850 ft.) S and 610 m (2000 ft.) E of NW corner of La Mesa Quadrangle, U.S. Geological Survey La Mesa Quadrangale, 7.5-minute, 1967, San Diego County, southern California.  [A retaining wall now covers the collecting site]
comments_evaluation: Age based on Pietsch et al., 2016. Changed min_ma from 41.3 to 41.2 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: From the lowermost part of the section. A single bed, 50-70 cm thick, approximately 11m below the Friars-Stadium contact. Magnetochron C21n (early Lutetian) at the Computer Media section, according to Walsh et al. (2005). The land-mammal assemblage from locality 3278 contains the insectivore Crypholestes?, a genus apparently endemic to\r\nsouthern California and only confidently identifed from strata of early Uintan "Age" (middle Eocene) (Novacek, 1976). The fossil assemblage from locality SDSNH 3278 contains molluscan taxa indicative of the middle Eocene "Transition Stage" of West Coast provincial molluscan biostratigraphy (Clark and Vokes, 1936; as refined by Givens and Kennedy, 1979). In terms of correlation with the standard European section, Givens (1974), Givens and Kennedy (1979), Saul (1983), and Squires (1984, 1987) considered the middle Eocene "Transition Stage" to be correlative with the middle part of the Lutetian Stage. \r\n

Malchus (1990) also compared the oysters from throughout the Gebel Dist Member with ones from the Egyptian eastern desert, dated by good ammonite age control as early Late Cenomanian.

collection_comments: estimated from map; locality within the Ocucaje area (Ica, Peru). Laguna Seca (LAG) is located about 30 km south- east of the Ocucaje district, on the east margin of the Ica River
comments_evaluation: Changed max_ma from 11.62 to 11.63 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: The lower marine sediments at LAG have yielded a diverse marine faunal assemblage including sharks, manta rays (Mylio- batis sp.) seabirds (penguins, Pelecaniformes indet.), cetaceans, phocid seals, and mollusks. The lamniform sharks Isurus hastalis and Carcharocles megalodon that are present occur elsewhere in upper Miocene beds (Ehret et al., 2012). Similarly, the pontoporiid dolphin Brachydelphis jahuayensis (MUSM 2425) is else- where restricted to the El Jahuay level (9.95 Ma; Muizon and Bellon, 1986; Lambert and Muizon, 2013). In addition, an inde- terminate penguin species (MUSM 2424; Spheniscus sp. 3; see Stucchi, 2007) also occurs in El Jahuay, Aguada de Lomas, and Montemar localities (9.95 Ma‚Äì7.30 Ma; Ehret et al., 2012). Fur- thermore, the phocid seal material (MUSM 2251) represents an undescribed Acrophoca-like species. Moreover, the presence of the mollusk Chione suggests that the deposit is at least 10 Ma, because it is identified elsewhere in 14‚Äì10 Ma deposits (DeVries, pers. comm., October 2010). Collectively, these fossil occurrences point to at least late Miocene age, but we could not exclude an older age. According to this, a correlation with the El Jahuay level (9.95 Ma, Tortonian) in the Sacaco area (Peru) is possible. Further investigation regarding the geology and geo- chronology of the locality is ongoing.

collection_aka: ca. 18 km NNW Nashville, Briar Mining Site, CertainTeed Mining
collection_comments: stated in text; In the 1980s, during the course of field investigations on the De Queen sauropod trackways (Pittman & Gillette, 1989), one of us (JGP) collected vertebrate remains and fossiliferous rock matrix from the upper part of the Holly Creek Formation, which cropped out in a drainage ditch excavated by the mining company (formerly Briar Mining Site, now CertainTeed Mining) in association with a reservoir to hold wastewater and mined residues.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: In Arkansas, the Trinity Group consists of the Delight Sand/Pike Gravel, the Dierks Limestone, the Holly Creek Formation (which interfingers with the Ultima Thule Gravel), the De Queen Formation, and the Paluxy Formation (Vanderpool, 1928; Miser & Purdue, 1929; McFarland, 2004).\r\nThe upper part of the Holly Creek Formation, at least, is thought to be Albian in age. This is based on similarity of the oyster assemblage (Ostrea franklini) to that found in the overlying De Queen Formation (Miser & Purdue, 1929), suggesting an Albian age for the upper boundary of the Holly Creek Formation. Also, the presence of the foraminiferan Orbitolina texana in the Ferry Lake Anhydrite, a correlative unit to anhydrite beds of the lower De Queen Formation, and the presence of the ammonite Douvilleiceras sp. within the De Queen Formation units at the CertainTeed mine, support an Albian age (Loucks & Longman, 1982; Pittman, 1984, 1985).

collection_comments: coastal locality here named MontanÃÉita/Ol√≥n (latitude 1 Ãä48‚Äô50.64" S, longitude 80 Ãä45‚Äô24.18" W). The MontanÃÉita/Ol√≥n (MO) locality (Fig 1) lies midway between the towns of MontanÃÉita and Ol√≥n (Santa Elena Province, Ecuador) and can only be accessed during low tides.
comments_evaluation: Changed max_ma from 28.1 to 27.82 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: Here, we provisionally identify the source horizon for MO-1 as the Zapotal Member of the Dos Bocas Formation, with names following Whittaker [25]. More study is needed to establish the proper terminology of the coastal strata outside, but closely-related to, the Progreso Basin. We did not find foraminiferans that might be used for dating. The presence of Carcharocles angustidens is consistent with a late Oligocene age suggested by Bristow. Elsewhere, in the East Pisco basin of Peru, C. angustidens is not reported from the vertebrate-bearing Chattian to Burdigalian Chilcatay Formation, in which the richest vertebrate-bearing horizon is Burdiga- lian [29‚Äì31]), but occurs in older units (M. Urbina and A. Altamirano (Departamento de Paleontolog ÃÅƒ±a de Vertebrados, Museo de Historia Natural, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos), personal communication, fide T.J. DeVries (Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, University of Washington, Seattle)). Thus, the age of MO-1 is consistent with a probable Chattian age (24 to 26 Ma), as shown by Bristow [23] (his Fig 3, Zapotal Member of Tosagua Formation).\r\n

collection_comments: estimated from map; Gebel Mokattam, near the Citadel, Cairo. Lat/long. estimate based on Cairo, Egypt.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: The unit has been assigned a upper Lutetian age in addition to an upper Middle Eocene-lower Upper Eocene age. It has a thickness of 133 m (4367 ft) at the type section near the Citadel, Cairo. The Mokattam Formartion at the type locality consists of three members. Collection is from the middle member (Cairo Buildingstone horizon). It has a thickness of 33 m or 108 ft). A bed is crowded with Nummulites at its top. This unit is equivalent to the Observatory Member in Helwan.

collection_comments: stated in text; Wadi Gharandal, on the eastern side of the Gulf of Suez. Lat/long. estimate based on Gebel Tanka, Egypt.
comments_evaluation: A Bartonian age gas been suggested for this unit; From PBDB: The upper Eocene in this area is divided into (from base to top), the Cardita Series, Green beds, gypsiderous marls, Tanak beds, and Red beds. The "Green Beds" are made up of green marls, 15-30 m (49-98 ft) thick. A Bartonian age gas been suggested for this unit.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; Al-Sarrar area, less than 90km from the coast of the Arabian Gulf. Rocks of the Dam formation are well exposed west of the road from Ain Dar Junction to Nu'ayriyah. Co-ordinates based on Ayn Dar.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Late Early Miocene. There are 3 Formations in the succession - the Hadruck, Dam and Hofuf (Hofuf overlies the others). Type section of the Dam Formation is Jabal al Lidam. The depth of the formation at Al-Sarrar varies, but is around 30m. Near the Arabian Gulf the Formation is entirely marine, with more continental facies inland. The Al-Sarrar area is an area of 'continental sediments interbedded with the marine series'.\r\nFauna has been collected from a number of localities which have been entered individually.\r\n

comments_evaluation: From PBDB: The Glen Rose formation spans through four ammonite zones with ages between latest Aptian and early Albian. Young 1974 suggested the Kasanskyella spathi ammonite zone is latest aptian, the Hypacanthoplites cragini zone is earliest Albian, the Douvilleiceras mammillatum and Hypacanthoplites comalensis zones are early Albian and may extend into the middle Albian. The Salenia texana Zone and Corbula bed fall within the mammillatum zone. The benthic foraminifera Orbitolina texana also suggests a late aptian - early albian age and is found in basal levels and in the upper member (Stricklin et al. 1971). Scott et al. (2007) estimated that the age of the Glen Rose Formation ranges from 113.3 to 108.0 Ma.

collection_comments: estimated from map; Tele-a-hiva at elevation of 400 feet, about 0.5 miles from army lookout tower [no longer present by 1970], at the scond stream north of Vaingana, Eua [Island], Tonga
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: No lithostratigraphic nomenclature for unit mentioned in 1970 or in later publications on Western Pacific Island Cenozoic strata (i.e. Ladd (1972, 1982). The collection is derived from a soft fossiliferous layer [unknown thickness] between two harder limestones. The exact extent of the richly fossiliferous bed is not known but is probably limited both horizontally and vertically. Eua is the oldest island in the Tonga island group that has a plutonic core and a series of volcanic rocks and sediments that are partly blanketed by thick limestones of late Eocene age. Younger volcanic rocks and sediments of late Tertiary age are also present.

stated in text; SPECIFIC LOCALITY: Large, disused quarry about 5 km west of Duncans police station, on the southern side of the main A1 (north coast) road, parish of Trelawny, central north Jamaica. COORDINATES: Estimate stated in text.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Early Miocene, on the basis of foraminiferal biostratigraphy.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; coordinate based on Durlston Head
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Durlston Formation is likely upper Berriasian in age based on magnetostratigraphy (Ogg et al. 1994; Ogg et al. 2008) and correlates to other upper Berriasian assemblages in Europe (e.g. Wimbledon and Hunt 1993).

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; SPECIFIC LOCATION: Cerova-Lieskove. Outcrop is at the western slope of the Male Karpaty Mts. at the eastern margin of the Vienna Basin. The deposits of the abandoned clay pit. LAT/LONG: estimated based on Kremsmunster, Austria.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Karpatian according to the authors, age based on Kovac et al., 2018. Changed min_ma from 2.588 to 2.58 based on ISC chart 2022

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates SU 431 719. A small overgrown quarry, located 340 m north-north-west of Boxford Church, on the east side of a country lane that runs parallel to the River Lambourne.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Uppermost Seaford or basal Newhaven Chalk Formation, M. coranguinum Zone, mid-Santonian. Collected from high in the northern face of the quarry, 30 cm above the 'Upper Hardground'.

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 448 722. A shallow pit in the middle of a field exposing up to 6 m of upper Santonian and lower Campanian chalk (Marsupites and pilula zones), c. 1.7 km east of Boxford.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 85.8 and 83.5 to 86.3 and 83.6 based on ISC chart 2022

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 448 722. A shallow pit in the middle of a field exposing up to 6 m of upper Santonian and lower Campanian chalk (Marsupites and pilula zones), c. 1.7 km east of Boxford.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 83.5 and 70.6 to 83.6 and 72.1 based on ISC chart 2022

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 835 098. A series of shallow pits in farmland that were infilled in the early 1940s. However, lumps of brown phosphatic chalk, known as Lavant Stone, can still be found in the field 475 m north-east of Stoke Clump.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 83.5 and 70.6 to 83.6 and 72.1 based on ISC chart 2022

collection_name: South Lodge Pit, Taplow, lower horizon
collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 906 819. South Lodge Pit is an abandoned quarry on the east bank of the River Thames near Taplow. The pit originally exposed two hardgrounds of middle and late Santonian age, overlain by a brown pelletal phosphatic chalks. It is currently somewhat degraded and only the upper horizon is visible.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 85.8 and 83.5 to 86.3 and 83.6 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: Lower phosphatic horizon is Uintacrinus socialis Zone, mid Santonian

collection_name: South Lodge Pit, Taplow, upper horizon
collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 906 819. South Lodge Pit is an abandoned quarry on the east bank of the River Thames near Taplow. The pit originally exposed two hardgrounds of middle and late Santonian age, overlain by a brown pelletal phosphatic chalks. It is currently somewhat degraded and only the upper horizon is visible.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 85.8 and 83.5 to 86.3 and 83.6 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: Upper phosphatic horizon is Marsupites testudinarius Zone, upper Santonian.

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. SU 601 065. A large, mostly back-filled, quarry on the south-west margin of Portsdown Hill, immediately adjacent to the M27 motorway. The middle part of the south-east face exposed faulted and contorted Campanian chalks with hardgrounds and locally developed calcarenites.
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 83.5 and 70.6 to 83.6 and 72.1 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: ?Spetisbury Member, Culver Chalk Formation, immediately above the Downend Main Hardground; G. quadrata and B. mucronata Overlap Zone, lower Campanian.

collection_comments: stated in text; Coordinates. D 339 135. This site is a mudslide on the Antrim Coast Road (A2) north of Drumnagreagh Port. Cretaceous rocks occur as blocks within the slipped Jurassic clays at the base of the hill and on the beach below the road, and sometimes as partly slipped blocks on the hillside.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Kilcoan Sands Member, Hibernian Greensand Formation; M. cortestudinarium Zone, Coniacian.

collection_comments: stated in text; Located approximately 2.7 km northwest of Garudamanglam, Tamil Nadu, India (N11¬∞05'01.9" E078¬∞55'14.1"). Vertebrate fossils were concentrated in a 0.01 km2 area ranging from N11¬∞05'47.9" to N11¬∞05'47.0" and 078¬∞53'58.0" to E078¬∞53'49.2".
comments_evaluation: Changed max and min ages from 99.6 and 93.5 to 100.5 and 93.9 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: "The Karai Formation is divided into a lower Odiyam Member, containing the Albian-Cenomanian boundary, and an upper Kunnam Member, containing the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary."; "The presence of the ammonite genera Sharpeiceras and Mariella (A. Gale, pers. comm., 2008) indicates an early Cenomanian age for the beds described here."

stated in text; WH 10001 was found in December, 2010, in the eastern part of the Wadi Al Hitan protected area, north of Garet Gehannam, on a broad open plain of eroding glauconitic siltstone and shale of the Gehannam Formation.
comments_evaluation: uppermost Bartonian and/or lowermost Priabonian age according to Underwood et al., 2011; From PBDB: The Basilosaurus locality and the entire open plain surrounding it are in the lower part of the Gehannam Formation, deposited during sea level rise following the Pr-1 low sea stand [31]. The Pr-1 low sea stand marks the Bartonian‚ÄìPriabonian stage/age boundary marking the transition from the middle to the late Eocene. The closest stratigraphic sections are Amin Strougo‚Äôs sections S329 and S340 some 5 km south of WH 10001, where the lower Gehannam Formation is in nannoplankton zone NP17 and in planktonic foraminiferal zone P14 [32]. Combining this evidence, the age of WH 10001 is approximately 37.5 Ma [33].

stated in text; The locality is accessible only by 4x4 vehicle, motorbike or camel train and there are no permanent tracks to the locality, although the main track linking Taouz with Zagora skirts Gara Sbaa Hill some 5 km to the north-west
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: There are no calcareous fossils in the Gara Sbaa Lagerst√§tte and, consequently, it has proved difficult to establish the precise age of the deposit. The underlying Kem Kem beds, in this region resting on folded Palaeozoic strata, has been dated as Albian or Cenomanian on account of its vertebrate remains. However, over most of the outcrop the vertebrate-bearing part of the Kem Kem beds is overlain by a series of variegated mudstones, thin sandstones and evaporites for which there is no age determination. These mudstones pass up into marls and shelly limestones and, at Gara Sbaa, into the fossiliferous laminated limestone described here. The marls and shelly limestones yield abundant examples of Ilymatogyra cf. africana, a bivalve that usually indicates a mid to early Late Cenomanian age (Ettachfini and Andreu, 2004; Dhondt and Jaillard, 2005). In the Goulmima region of southern Morocco laterally equivalent carbonates of the Akrabou Formation have been dated as Late Cenomanian to Turonian on account of their marine benthic and planktonic foraminiferan assemblages (Ettachfini and Andreu, 2004). It is highly likely that the Gara Sbaa Lagerst√§tte is of Late Cenomanian or Early Turonian age but because there are no strata overlying the laminites, a minimum age cannot be determined at this locality.\r\nPreviously under Gara Sbaa member of the Akrabou Formation, but the Gara Sbaa unit is now considered a Formation, and is older than the Akrabou Formation (see Ibrahim et al. 2020)

collection_comments: estimated from map; 2.25 mi. SW of BM 961, Santa Susana, Calabasa quad, Simi Hills, Ventura Co., California, according to Miller (1947), for Nautilus hallidayi. It is not clear whether all specimens come from the same location.
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: Originally described as "Martinez," but now belongs to Santa Susana Formation. Nautilids come from Zinsmeister's (1983) "assemblage A" which spans the lower three-quarters of the Santa Susana. Planktonic foraminifera suggest a P4 and P5 age (Heitman, 1983) and calcareous nannoplankton belong to zones CP5-CP8 (Filewicz & Hill, 1983), indicating a Thanetian age.\r\n\r\n[Squires 2018] Waring (1917) listed the mollusks found at this locality and referred to them erroneously as ‚ÄòMartinez‚Äô species of ‚Äòearly Eocene‚Äô age. The type locality of O. plectata plots in upper lower Paleocene (upper Danian Stage) strata mapped as the Las Virgenes Sandstone (Squires, 1981).

collection_comments: based on political unit; S of the Manatee River, 17.7 km east of Bradenton
comments_evaluation: Age of the Peace River Formation after Missimer 1999; From PBDB: JA: Hemphillian based on AEO results; upper beds\r\n\r\nMissimer 1999: The Peace River Formation was deposited from about 11 to 4.3 Ma. It is separated from the underlying, middle Miocene Arcadia Formation by an unconformity with a hiatus of 2 to 4 m.y. The unconformity separating the shallow marine sequence (late Miocene) from the overlying deltaic sequence (early Pliocene) has a hiatal gap of 2 to 6 m.y. depending on geographic location.

collection_name: Waipara River, upstream from Laidmore Bridge (M3/f9254)
collection_comments: estimated from map; Waipara River right bank, 800 m upstream from Laidmore Bridge, mid-Canterbury, South Island, New Zealand (New Zealand Topographical Map Series NZMS 1:50,000, sheet M34: 2476068 5793986; co-ordinates 43.06242 S, 172.58319 E). [Coordinates converted to WGS84 here]
comments_evaluation: Changed max_ma from 70.6 to 72.1 based on ISC chart 2022; From PBDB: The lithology was defined by Webb (1966) as the Laidmore Formation, a term also used in Welles and Gregg (1971). Later Warren and Speden (1978, p. 25) proposed that the Laidmore Formation be considered as a unit of the Conway Siltstone (Warren and Speden 1978); this was subsequently modified and published as the Conway Formation (Browne and Field 1985) and is now widely accepted as such (Wilson et al. 2005). The material was collected 6 m below the top of the Conway Formation. Wilson et al. (2005) extracted a sample from the matrix surrounding the holotype of P. waiparaensis and recorded a microflora dominated by taxa such as Manumiella seelandica (Lange, 1969), Manumiella druggii (Stover, 1973), Fibrocysta bipolaris (Cookson and Eisenack, 1965) and Alterbidinium longicornutum Roncaglia and Schi√∏ler, 1997, an assemblage that confirms a late Maastrichtian age, close to the Cretaceous ‚ÅÑ Palaeogene boundary.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark;
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: fossils are apparently from a single bed\r\nThe Glen Rose formation spans through four ammonite zones with ages between latest Aptian and early Albian. Young 1974 suggested the Kasanskyella spathi ammonite zone is latest aptian, the Hypacanthoplites cragini zone is earliest Albian, the Douvilleiceras mammillatum and Hypacanthoplites comalensis zones are early Albian and may extend into the middle Albian. The Salenia texana Zone and Corbula bed fall within the mammillatum zone. The benthic foraminifera Orbitolina texana also suggests a late aptian - early albian age and is found in basal levels and in the upper member (Stricklin et al. 1971). Scott et al. (2007) estimated that the age of the Glen Rose Formation ranges from 113.3 to 108.0 Ma.

comments_evaluation: From PBDB: The precise age of H√¢qel and Hjo√ªla varies according to different authors. ln his comprehensive sedimentological study H√ºckel (1970) divided the Cenomanian Limestones into seven units and concluded that H√¢qel (unite V) and Hjo√ªla (unite IV) were deposited during the later Lower Cenomanian. Owing to the occurrence of the ammonite Allocrioceras annulatum as a member of the Metoicoceras geslinianum Zone, Wippich & Lehmann (2004) confirmed the conclusions of Hemleben (1977) and dated H√¢qel and Hjo√ªla as Upper Cenomanian (Fig. 2). Dalla Vecchia et al. (2002) considered H√¢qel and Hjo√ªla as lower Upper Cenomanian, because Nammo√ªra (another fossil-rich locality a few kilometres in the South of Hjo√ªla and slightly younger than H√¢qel and Hjo√ªla) is dated as Middle Cenomanian.

collection_comments: based on nearby landmark; Outcrops in the Siemien are and sediments penetrated by the borehole Luszawa in the Lublin region, Polish lowland, Poland. Coordinate esimate based on town of Lublin, Poland
comments_evaluation: From PBDB: No lithostratigraphic unit given in text or found in literature search. Deposits are however less than 10 m thick, overlain by Quaternary sands. Assigned to Bartonian on the basis of similarity of faunal assemblage to Bartonian of England. Furthermore, analysis of planktonic foraminifers shows the unit to be the Globigerapsis semiinvolute Zone, that is in the lower part of the Upper Eocene, and on the basis of coccoliths to be in the Discoaster nodifer biozone, that is uppermost Middle and lowermost Upper Eocene.
